subject: US MARKET WRAP 12 April 2019: SPX above 2900 as earnings season gets into full swing
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: JPM beats as capital markets rebound; WFC reports weak NII guidance; Michigan sentiment weak; trade optimism.

* NEXT WEEK: Monday: NY Fed Manufacturing, Tuesday: UK Labour Market Report, German ZEW Survey, US Industrial Production, NAHB Housing Market Index, Wednesday: Indonesia elections, UK CPI, Eurozone CPI (Final), US Current Account, Canadian CPI, Thursday: Australian Labour Market Report, UK Retail Sales, Philly Fed, US Retail Sales, Friday: Good Friday Holiday. Click here  for RANsquawk’s Week In Focus Preview.

* TRADE: The US and China have agreed to measures that US officials believe will encourage China to avoid currency manipulation by requiring enhanced disclosure of economic actions, according to WSJ sources. Elsewhere, China officials told the WTO that Australia's restriction on Chinese 5G technology is discriminative and appears to violate WTO rules; officials said that country-specific restrictions on 5G cannot address concerns about cybersecurity, or make any one safe. From the European perspective, the EU Commission reportedly has made a list of US imports to potentially impose tariffs on due to the Boeing (BA) WTO case, with the list set to target around EUR 20bln of US goods, according to an EU diplomat.

* UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN: April's prelim print fell more than expected (sentiment 96.9 vs expected 98.0) as did the expectations component (85.8 vs expected 88.5), although the conditions measure rose to 114.2 vs expected 112.5. Both inflation gauges fell. Analysts noted that the April weakness was a function of weaker expectations, and comes despite the recent boost in stock prices, which Capital Economics says, adds to the evidence that the recent slowdown in economic growth will be sustained this year.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES $0.31 HIGHER AT $63.89; BRENT (M9) SETTLES $0.72 HIGHER AT $71.55. Oil prices ended the week on the front foot, catching a tailwind from a risk on sentiment and a weaker dollar. Shortly after the European equity open major risks assets saw a (seemingly unexplained) leg higher, with equities and commodities surging whilst treasuries sold off. On top of macro themes, the head of Libya’s NOC said that the ongoing conflict between the eastern and western forces could “wipe out” production, the country has a 1.1mln BPD capacity, a fair chunk which bulls have been paying close attention too. The market also took no cues from data out of China which showed the super nation’s imports falling to a six-month low of 9.26mln BPD, which “does not bode well for Chinese oil demand growth prospects,” analysts at PVM comment. US drillers increased oil rig count for the second consecutive week, according to data from Baker Hughes which showed oil rigs +2 at 833, gas rigs -5 at 189, and total rigs -3 at 1022.

* SPX +0.66% at 2908, NDX +0.44% at 7628, DJI +1%% at 26412. SECTORS: Communications +0.61%, Cons Discretionary +0.6%, Cons Staples +0.3%, Energy +0.2%, Financials +1.9%, Healthcare -1%, Industrials +1.3%, Materials +1.3%, Tech +0.7%, Telecoms +1.2%, Utilities +0.5%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Anadarko (APC) shares shot higher after news emerged that Chevron (CVX) was to acquire its smaller peer at USD 65 per share. Chevron shares fell on news of the deal. Occidental Petroleum Corp (OXY) shares fell on the open, after reports that it had made a bid for Anadarko but been rejected. Disney (DIS) shares opened at all-time highs after the film production co. held a press conference which revealed new details about its soon to be released Disney+ online streaming service. Rival online streaming co. Netflix (NFLX) shares fell at the open. JP Morgan Chase (JPM) shares opened higher after the firm released its Q1 earnings report, where it beat expectations across the board, most notably in EPS and revenue. On the earnings optimism, other big investment banks (GS, MS, BAC, C) also opened higher and held on to gains throughout the session. An outlier was Wells Fargo (WFC), whose shares initially opened higher after the bank beat earnings expectations before falling lower after its CFO announced that they expected NII to fall up to 5%. PG&E (PCG) shares shot higher as news emerged that California Governor Newton had issued a report laying out a fire fund for utilities, a possible form of financial assistance for the energy utility company.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 15 TICKS LOWER AT 123-03. Following an upbeat set of China data, that reassured investors about the stabilisation seen in the World’s second largest economy, the risk tone became constructive, although the reaction was somewhat delayed. The result was selling of the Treasury curve, and yields are higher by between 4bps and 6.5bps at settlement. The selling saw a pause after a soft Michigan survey, which lifted the T-Note off of lows. Major curve spreads were mixed into a quiet close. 

* Weekly FX Wrap: easy ECB, neutral FOMC, another ‘Brextension’ and EM divergence.

* DXY: Revived risk appetite over the last session of the week and order-driven moves elsewhere have weighed on the Dollar, especially against the high beta Aussie and Euro. Hence, having reclaimed 97.000 status after the latest Fed minutes on ‘super Wednesday’, above forecast PPI and a fresh 50 year/cycle low in weekly claims the index is slipping to fresh wtd lows at 96.742 amidst broad Usd losses vs other G10s bar the even more safe-haven Jpy.

* AUD: As noted above, the Aussie has been a major beneficiary of improved risk sentiment ahead of the weekend, and belatedly Chinese trade data showing a much wider the expected trade surplus. Aud/Usd has now rebounded more firmly above the 0.7150 level that has been pivotal this week after fading gains made in wake of relatively neutral comments made by RBA deputy Governor Debelle compared to official guidance or nuances in the official policy meeting statement last week. However, 0.7200 looms and the 200 DMA at 0.7195 vs a 0.7188 high so far.

* NZD/EUR: The Kiwi has largely coat-tailed its Antipodean counterpart and risk-on/off fluctuations, but lagged on the more overtly dovish RBNZ OCR guidance. Nzd/Usd is currently back around the top of a 0.6773-11 range and stronger than is began the week around 0.6734 with attention turning towards next week’s NZ CPI data that could be key in terms of determining whether the Central Bank eases in early May. Similarly, the single currency is putting in a strong performance and reversing more of its mid-week ECB inspired losses to set a new high vs the Greenback and other major currency peers, with technical resistance near 1.1250 finally breached and the 1.1300 handle as well. To recap, more confident/upbeat rhetoric following President Draghi’s rather cautious if not downbeat post-meeting press conference and Q&A helped the Euro regain composure, but the telling boost came via a big buy order in Eur/Jpy at Friday’s Tokyo fixing linked to an M&A deal. Note, the cross has now been up to 126.76 and Eur/Usd just a few pips shy of the next line of chart resistance circa 1.1330.

* GBP/CAD: Cable has also carved out fresh peaks on the final session of the week around 1.3130 vs lows of 1.3019 and an ‘open’ not too far away (1.3034), mainly due to the generally soft Buck, but also due to a combination of Brexit relief and optimism after Article 50 was extended again and with a flexible leave earlier than October 31 if you can find a deal clause. The EU rejected PM May’s June 30 request, but another no deal nightmare has been averted to allow extra time for Parliament to come up with an alternative or approve the current WA with tweaks to the body of the PD rather than add-ons. The Tories and Labour are still in talks to strike an accord, but Easter recess has started and there will be a (welcome?) slowdown in the sheer volume of headlines that could give MPs a chance to reflect and take stock. Elsewhere, the Loonie has been volatile within 1.3400-1.3275 trading parameters and mostly strengthening alongside oil prices after last Friday’s disappointing Canadian jobs report and will now be eyeing BoC’s Lane for potential pointers ahead of next week’s CPI data and the Business Outlook Survey.

* CHF/JPY/NOK/SEK: Mixed and inter-changing fortunes for the traditional ‘safe-havens’ and Scandi Crowns with the Franc weakening vs the Dollar to multi-week lows not far from 1.0050 before rebounding as the Usd weakened back towards parity and not far from best levels (0.9975). However, the Jpy has gradually retreated back to where it kicked off and below between a 110.83-111.99 band amidst some bleak Japanese data and more dovish BoJ statements alongside the waxing and waning of overall risk sentiment. Meanwhile, techs, inflation data, Norges Bank and Riksbank guidance have all been factors and independent drivers for the Nok and Sek, but the former has also benefited from the ongoing bull run in crude to stay on course to close out the week with net gains vs the Eur despite the single currency’s strength.

* EM: In keeping with the divergence noted above, the Try’s trials and tribulations continue on more political wrangling over the recent elections and an underwhelming Turkish Economic Plan, while the Zar goes from strength to strength on the wave of positive ratings reviews and the hope of reform.

* CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY:

RANsquawk Central Bank Weekly 12 Apr 2019: Reviewing FOMC, ECB, RBA, BCB; Previewing RBA mins, BOK. To download the report, please click here.

content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) Q1 adj. EPS USD 2.65 vs. exp. USD 2.32, revenue USD 29.25bln vs. exp. USD 28.07bln. FICC Sales & Trading Revenue USD 3.73bln vs. exp USD 3.67bln. Investment Banking Revenue USD 1.75bln vs. exp. USD 1.63bln
  • Chevron (CVX), Anadarko (APC) – Oil major Chevron is to acquire Anadarko for USD 65 per share, totalling USD 33bln in equity value (representing a 39% premium), in a 25% cash and 75% stock transaction
  • Disney (DIS), Netflix (NFLX) - The film production co. announced yesterday evening that its Disney+ streaming service would be available in the US for $6.99 per month

 

12th April 2019

EARNINGS

  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) Q1 adj. EPS USD 2.65 vs. exp. USD 2.32, revenue USD 29.25bln vs. exp. USD 28.07bln. FICC Sales & Trading Revenue USD 3.73bln vs. exp USD 3.67bln. Investment Banking Revenue USD 1.75bln vs. exp. USD 1.63bln. Equities Sales & Trading Revenue USD 1.74bln vs. exp. USD 1.73bln. Adj. Revenue USD 29.85bln vs. exp. USD 28.36bln. CET1 Ratio 12.1% vs. exp. 12%. (Newswires)
  • PNC Bank (PNC) Q1 diluted EPS USD 2.61 vs. Exp. USD 2.59, revenue USD 4.3bln vs. Exp. USD 4.25bln. Sees Q2 NII up low single digits vs. Q1. Sees Q2 fee income up mid-single digits. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC) Q1 diluted USD 1.20 vs. Exp. USD 1.08, revenue USD 21.6bln vs. Exp. USD 20.87bln. NIM declines 3bps to 2.91% vs. Exp. 2.93%. Quarterly mortgage banking income USD 708mln vs previous USD 497mln in Q4; says residential mortgage loan originations in Q1 was USD 33bln, down from USD 38bln in Q4. Raises common stock dividend to USD 0.45 from 0.43. CET1 Ratio 11.9% vs. Exp. 11.6%. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty said that data from China suggests that the co.’s share of the region’s smartphone installed base grew by 3% YY in March. (Newswires)
  • Apple (AAPL), Disney (DIS) – Disney CEO Bob Iger said that the upcoming Disney+ service is likely to be included on Apple TV. (AppleInsider)
  • Chevron (CVX), Anadarko (APC) – Oil major Chevron is to acquire Anadarko for USD 65 per share, totalling USD 33bln in equity value (representing a 39% premium), in a 25% cash and 75% stock transaction, in a deal that it expects to unlock run-rate synergies of approximately USD 2 billion, and will be accretive to FCF and earnings one year after close, which it expects to close in H2 2019. Chevron will issue 200mln shares and pay USD 8bln in cash; the co. will also assume USD 15bln of Anadarko’s debt. Chevron is looking to increase its share repurchase programme to USD 5bln from USD 4bln after the deal closes. (Newswires)
  • Disney (DIS), Netflix (NFLX) - The film production co. announced yesterday evening that its Disney+ streaming service would be available in the US for $6.99 from the 12th November and next year in Europe and Asia (and is weighing a Latin America launch). Disney will also likely bundle its Hulu, ESPN+ and Disney+ service for a discounted price, with Disney+ exclusively including key franchises (Marvel, Star Wars etc.) and plan to pursue an aggressive ad campaign in the run up to launch. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) – the pharma co. announced that the FDA had approved an expanded label for Ketyruda, its cancer treatment therapy, after it demonstrated stronger survival rates. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • General Motors (GM), Amazon (AMZN) – Talks between GM owned electric truck maker Rivian and Amazon are reported to have collapsed. (Newswires)
  • Telecoms Names (VZ, T, S, TMUS) – Reportedly the Trump administration plans to auction airwaves speed to the nation’s adoption of 5G wireless communications and is planning on devoting more than USD 20bln on improving mobile connections in rural areas. US President Trump will hold a 5G event this afternoon at the White House. (Newswires)
  • The Mosaic Company (MOS) – The mining co. announced that it would idle production at its phosphate mines in Tapira and Catalao, Brazil in order to comply with new Brazilian regulations governing mining tales. The company has sufficient inventory stocks to meet near-term market requirements. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Align Technology (ALGN) – In a regulatory filing, the health care co. expects to record charges of between USD 26mln-30mln related to the closure of stores. (Newswires)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The co.’s YouTube unit is changing the criteria of how it measures successful videos due to reports of scandalous behaviour on the platform. Elsewhere, WSJ reports that the German price-comparison service Idealo Internet is suing Google in the EU over its dominance in the search-engine market. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – Senator and presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has proposed a new 75 tax on corporate profits, where she estimates USD 1trln of tax revenue would be raised in a 10-year period, she specifically cited Amazon as a company that does not pay enough tax currently. (AP)
  • Biogen (BIIB) – The pharma co. is to present data on the progressive nature of spinal muscular atrophy at the Muscular Dystrophy Association. (Newswires)
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) – The pharma co., alongside Novo Nordisk (NVO), will collaborate by combining their respective pipelines in non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, or NASH. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric auto maker is disputing reports that it is putting its plans, to expand its Gigafactory on hold, which is a joint venture with Panasonic. ‘Both Tesla and Panasonic continue to invest substantial funds into the Gigafactory’ said a Tesla spokesperson. The co. announced it has taken the base version of the Model 3 vehicle off its website. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alaska Air (ALK) – On a combined basis for all operations, the airline reported an increase in traffic of 0.5% and capacity of 1.3% YY. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices are mildly higher [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%]; E-mini futures reclaimed the 2900 level and Chevron announced a USD 33bln deal, ahead of US banks reporting
  • China reported a trade balance of USD 32.64bln significantly above expectations of USD 7.05bln
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Import/Export Prices, University of Michigan (Preliminary), Chinese Trade Balance, ECB's Weidmann & Praet, BoE's Carney
  • Earnings: JP Morgan Chase, Wells Fargo & PNC Financial

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed following an indecisive lead from Wall St. with participants tentative ahead of the latest Chinese trade data and big bank earnings in US. ASX 200 (+0.8%) benefitted from early outperformance in its largest weighted financials sector as top lender CBA gained on the reports it plans to reduce 10k workers, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) exporters found solace from favourable currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp (U/C) lagged amid weakness in tech and gambling names, as well as cautiousness heading into the latest Chinese trade data. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as stocks in Japan remained afloat although downside for bonds was stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs and with SoftBank pricing a record JPY 500bln offering.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral for a 2nd consecutive week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7220 (Prev. 6.7088)

Monetary Authority of Singapore kept policy unchanged as expected, while it lowered 2019 all-items inflation forecasts to 0.5%-1.5% from 1.0%-2.0% and sees GDP growth to be slightly below mid-point of 1.5%-3.5% projected range. (Newswires)

Chinese Trade Balance USD 32.64B vs. Exp. 7.05B (Prev. 4.08B)

- Chinese Exports YY* Mar 14.2% vs. Exp. 7.3% (Prev. -20.8%)

- Chinese Imports YY* Mar -7.6% vs. Exp. -1.3% (Prev. -5.2%)

- Chinese Yuan-Denominated Trade Balance (Mar) 220B (Prev. 34.46B)

- Chinese Yuan-Denominated Exports (Mar) +21.3% (Prev. -16.6%)

- Chinese Yuan-Denominated Imports (Mar) -1.8% (Prev. -0.3%)

China customs spokesman says impact on China trade from US-Sino tensions is generally controllable and expects China imports and exports to show mild growth in Q2, Q1 Yuan-denominated exports to US -3.7%, imports -28.3%, March exports to US +10.6%, imports -21% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q1) Q/Q 2.0% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires) Singapore GDP (Q1) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.9%)

US

Fed Chair Powell (neutral) reiterated that rates are in the right place and that China's soft patch impacted US growth outlook, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Italian Economy Minister Tria says cutting income tax is necessary and the Italian government will decide in Autumn how to go about it, adds that he believes Italy can overcome EU objection over excessive debt and rules out a ‘traditional’ budget correction, but adds that there could be adjustments. (Newswires)

German Economy Ministry notes that the state of the economy is currently mixed with weakness in the industrial sector, however, there is strength in the domestic impetus, weakness in the manufacturing sector will be significantly weaker in H1 2019 compared to H1 2018, however, softness in the sector in Q1 will be more than compensated by other parts of the economy. (Newswires)

German government will likely reduce their 2019 GDP forecast to 0.5% from 1.0% next week with 2020 growth expected at 1.5%, according to sources. (Newswires) For reference, this is similar to German press reports yesterday.

EQUITIES

European equities are marginally higher thus far [Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%] after having erased losses seen at the open. Broad-based gains are being seen across major bourses given the recent upturn of risk appetite wherein DAX breached 12k to the upside. Similarly, E-mini Jun’19 futures reclaimed the 2900 level ahead of the all time high just under 2940, last seen in October 2018. Back to Europe, sectors are mixed with outperformance in material names given the spike higher in sentiment-driven base metals. In terms of notable movers, Plus500 (-25%) fell over 40% at one point after reporting an 82% drop in revenue Y/Y, with IG Group (-3.0%) dragged lower in sympathy. Finally, markets are awaiting earnings from JP Morgan (11:55BST) and Wells Fargo (13:00BST) to kick off US earnings season.

Chevron Corp (CVX) announce agreement to acquire Anadarko (APC) for USD 33bln at USD 65/share; will assume estimated net debt of USD 15bln. Anadarko are higher by around 20% in pre-market.

FX

EUR/JPY - Eur/Usd and Usd/Jpy are both testing big figure levels, at 1.1300 and 112.00 respectively where decent option expiries lie (1.2 bn and 1.1 bn), but the move appears to be M&A driven and via the Eur/Jpy cross that spiked through 126.00 at the Tokyo fix overnight. Specifically, a 3 bn buy order is said to have been filled between 125.70 and 126.29, with the proceeds touted to be related to MUFJ’s purchase of a DZ Bank unit. Note, Eur/Jpy has now extended gains to circa 126.60 and the single currency is seeing spill-over buying across the board to around 1.1310 vs the Dollar and 0.8656 against Sterling where stops were expected on a break of 0.8650. Technically, 1.1316 in Eur/Usd may cap the upside as it forms 55 DMA and Fib resistance, while for Usd/Jpy several chart levels reside not far above 112.00, including the 200 WMA (112.04), a Fib (112.06) and the 112.13-16 ytd peak.

AUD/CAD/NZD - All benefiting from a more risk-on tone unfolding during the EU session and rebounding from lows vs their US counterpart, with the Aussie retesting 0.7150+ and Loonie paring losses from 1.3390 through 1.3350, but the Kiwi hampered to a degree by some weak NZ data overnight as it falls short of 0.6750. Note, Aud/Usd is now back within the realms of 1 bn expiries between 0.7150-55, as the DXY slips back under 97.000 again, albeit mainly due to the aforementioned Eur’s ascent and its biggest weighting in the index.

CHF/GBP - Also firmer vs the Greenback, as the Franc pares more losses from multi-week lows and inches closer to parity and Cable retains the bulk of its Brexit extension optimism within a 1.3050-80 range, but remains toppy on approaches to 1.3100 or just above given resistance around earlier April highs.

EM - Usd/Try has advanced further amidst the political turmoil and uncertainty over recent regional elections as the official Board has deferred a decision on a recount in one area of Istanbul that the ruling AK Party is contesting. The Lira lurched down below 5.8100 at one stage and closer to lows seen last month around 5.8490.

FIXED INCOME

Bonds have sharply decelerated after a relatively calm and measured initial downturn from fresh session highs, with Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries just off 165.01, 127.28 and 123-08+ troughs vs 165.79, 127.95 and 123-21+ at best. The catalyst seems clear given an almost as abrupt rise in equities, but the rationale or driver is far from certain unless a major asset reallocation is unearthed at some stage, or some bullish stock-specific news.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent recently received a bout of demand as risk-on sentiment took the wheel, wherein the former reclaimed USD 64/bbl whilst the latter gained more ground above USD 71/bbl. Oil is poised for its third consecutive week of gains, as the benchmarks price in potential supply disruptions emanating from Libyan tensions. NOC Head Sanala warned that a renewal of fighting could wipe out the nation’s crude production which stood at 1.1mln BPD in March, according to secondary sources. Elsewhere, Europe’s largest oil refinery, Shell’s 404K BPD Pernis remains restricted at 65% of its normal output amid strikes conducted by a Dutch trade union which is expected to last until at least Monday. Finally, China’s trade report noted that the country’s crude oil imports in the first quarter rose 8.2% Y/Y, although March imports fell to the lowest since 2018. In the metals complex, gold remains below the USD 1300/oz level after having lost the mark as the Greenback recouped some recent losses. Elsewhere, copper prices received a boost from the risk appetite around the market. The red metal breached its 100 DMA to the upside at 2.8974/lb before briefly trading above the 2.950/lb level.

Libya NOC chief said oil and gas exports face biggest threat since 2011 given the recent fighting, subsequently stating that a renewal of fighting could wipe out the nations crude production. (Newswires)

Norway's Petroleum directorate states that preliminary March oil production was 1.396mln BPD. March production lagged its forecasts by 1.5% due to technical issues at some oil fields. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: JPMorgan (JPM) Q1 2019 earnings due 1155 BST/0655 EDT
content:
ESTIMATED EARNINGS RELEASE TIME: 11:55 BST/06:55 EDT

  • CONSTITUENT: DJIA (2.7% weight), SPX (1.4% weight).
  • SECTOR: Financials/Diversified Banks. Peers: BAC, C, CMA, USB, WFC. Other peers: SCHW, ETFC, GS, MS, RJF.
  • PERFORMANCE SINCE LAST REPORT (15 JAN): +7.3% (vs financials sector +7.7%, vs diversified banks 5.8%)
  • YESTERDAY CLOSE (USD): 106.23
  • VWAP (USD): 5-day 105.43; 30-day 103.42; 90-day 103.29.
  • OPTIONS-IMPLIED PRICE SWING (+/-): 2.1%

Q1 2019 EXPECTATIONS:

  • Q1 EPS (USD): 2.32 (prev. 1.98 vs exp. 2.20, first miss in 16 qtrs)
  • Q1 REVENUE (USD): 28.07bln (prev. 26.1bln, -2.1% surprise).
  • FY 2019 EPS: ~9.85
  • CO. GUIDANCE FOR Q1: Expects 1Q19 NII to be approximately flat Q/Q, market dependent (~14.35bln). Expects 1Q19 expense to be up mid-single digits Y/Y. CFO said sees a more constructive market tone in Q1, one quarter of fixed income declines did not signal a trend, and that he saw no signs of a turn in the credit cycle in Q1. Market revenues are to fall in the “high teens” in Q1 following the strong Q1 2018, driven by lower FX and EM units. Medium-term profitability targets lowered for IB as the division required more capital in 2019.

STOCK RATING:

  • ANALYSTS: Of 30 analysts covering JPM, strong buy: 7, buy: 7, hold: 15, sell: 1
  • RECENT RATING MOVES: 3 upgrades and 15 downgrades in the last 90 days.
  • MEDIAN PRICE TARGET (USD): 115.00 (9.2% upside vs closing price).
  • SECTOR: S&P 500 finance sector earnings estimated to grow by 6.9% this quarter; revenue is seen rising 4.6%.

FACTORS:

  • CAPITAL MARKETS: FICC and equities seen -14% YY, according to RBC (f/c -11% FICC trading, -17% decline in equities trading). Prev. equities -17% QQ to USD 1.3bln (+15% YY); prev. FICC -35% QQ at USD 1.9bln (-16% YY).
  • NIM/NII: Barclays forecasts NIM at 2.56% (+2bps) on an increase in loan yields, partially offset by rising deposit costs.
  • SHARE BUYBACKS: The 2018 capital plan authorised a 20.7bln share repurchase facility, of which 10.4bln of the authorisation remained at the end of 2018.
  • DIVIDEND: Quarterly dividend USD 0.80/shr (paid 30 April, ex-div on 5 April).
  • PREVIOUS EARNINGS REPORT (Q4 2018, released 15 Jan): First earnings miss in 16 quarters. Higher than expected loan loss provisions (added to card and wholesale reserves) and managed tax rate, lower than anticipated fee income driven by FICC, home lending revenues were 8% lower YY.

 

Sources: RANsquawk, Refinitiv, Factset, RBC, Barclays, Trefis

content:
EUR/JPY

Eur/Usd and Usd/Jpy are both testing big figure levels, at 1.1300 and 112.00 respectively where decent option expiries lie (1.2 bn and 1.1 bn), but the move appears to be M&A driven and via the Eur/Jpy cross that spiked through 126.00 at the Tokyo fix overnight. Specifically, a 3 bn buy order is said to have been filled between 125.70 and 126.29, with the proceeds touted to be related to MUFJ’s purchase of a DZ Bank unit. Note, Eur/Jpy has now extended gains to circa 126.60 and the single currency is seeing spill-over buying across the board to around 1.1310 vs the Dollar and 0.8656 against Sterling where stops were expected on a break of 0.8650. Technically, 1.1316 in Eur/Usd may cap the upside as it forms 55 DMA and Fib resistance, while for Usd/Jpy several chart levels reside not far above 112.00, including the 200 WMA (112.04), a Fib (112.06) and the 112.13-16 ytd peak.

AUD/CAD/NZD 

All benefiting from a more risk-on tone unfolding during the EU session and rebounding from lows vs their US counterpart, with the Aussie retesting 0.7150+ and Loonie paring losses from 1.3390 through 1.3350, but the Kiwi hampered to a degree by some weak NZ data overnight as it falls short of 0.6750. Note, Aud/Usd is now back within the realms of 1 bn expiries between 0.7150-55, as the DXY slips back under 97.000 again, albeit mainly due to the aforementioned Eur’s ascent and its biggest weighting in the index.

CHF/GBP

Also firmer vs the Greenback, as the Franc pares more losses from multi-week lows and inches closer to parity and Cable retains the bulk of its Brexit extension optimism within a 1.3050-80 range, but remains toppy on approaches to 1.3100 or just above given resistance around earlier April highs.

EM

Usd/Try has advanced further amidst the political turmoil and uncertainty over recent regional elections as the official Board has deferred a decision on a recount in one area of Istanbul that the ruling AK Party is contesting. The Lira lurched down below 5.8100 at one stage and closer to lows seen last month around 5.8490.

subject: Bunds: straddling parity within a tight range
content: A rather subdued start to Friday’s session for the 10 year German debt future after a modest mark-up to 165.64 only saw follow-through buying to 165.66 vs yesterday’s 165.58 Eurex close before a fade and pull-back to 165.51 where underlying prevented a deeper pull-back. More recently Bunds have meandered in an even narrower band with just a knee-jerk dip on a significantly wider than forecast Chinese trade surplus and subsequent recovery to a very marginal new intraday high of 165.70. In short, consolidation seems the order of the day (for now at least) after the post-ECB rally faded and above forecast US data prompted a retreat on Thursday. Ahead, Eurozone ip is forecast to decline after a strong showing last time, but could pleasantly surprise following better data from some member states and ECB speakers are scheduled (Weidmann and Praet).

ASIA

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian indices are mixed as markets await Chinese trade data and the start of US earnings season
  • France is reportedly against reopening EU-US trade talks, but will not block them given that a majority supports the talks
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Industrial Production, US Import/Export Prices, University of Michigan (Preliminary), Chinese Trade Balance, ECB's Weidmann & Praet, BoE's Carney
  • Earnings: JP Morgan Chase, Wells Fargo & PNC Financial

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed following an indecisive lead from Wall St. with participants tentative ahead of the latest Chinese trade data and big bank earnings in US. ASX 200 (+0.7%) benefitted from early outperformance in its largest weighted financials sector as top lender CBA gained on the reports it plans to reduce 10k workers, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) exporters found solace from favourable currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) lagged amid weakness in tech and gambling names, as well as cautiousness heading into the latest Chinese trade data. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as stocks in Japan remained afloat although downside for bonds was stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for nearly JPY 1tln of JGBs and with SoftBank pricing a record JPY 500bln offering.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral for a 2nd consecutive week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7220 (Prev. 6.7088)

Monetary Authority of Singapore kept policy unchanged as expected, while it lowered 2019 all-items inflation forecasts to 0.5%-1.5% from 1.0%-2.0% and sees GDP growth to be slightly below mid-point of 1.5%-3.5% projected range. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q1) Q/Q 2.0% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires) Singapore GDP (Q1) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.9%) 

UK/EU

BoE Governor Carney said business investment has stalled since the 2016 referendum and that it is having an effect on productivity, while he added that the UK labour market is incredibly tight and business uncertainty is 'through the roof'. (Newswires)

ECB sources said policymakers are leaning towards offering a negative rate on TLTRO to banks that meet lending targets and that policymakers are sceptical on a tiered deposit rate. (Newswires)

France is said to object to re-opening trade talks with the US but will not block discussions since there is a majority of EU members who support the process. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY trickled below the 97.00 level as it gave back some of the prior session’s data-inspired gains in which encouraging jobless claims and firmer than expected PPI numbers subsequently dampened hopes for a Fed rate cut this year. Nonetheless, the greenback’s major counterparts have benefitted from the overnight pullback with outperformance in EUR/USD after it broke through the 5- and 20-day moving averages on its quest towards the 1.1300 level, while gains were exacerbated by cross-related flows as EUR/JPY tripped through stops at 126.00 post-Tokyo fix and some also suggested flows from a previously announced USD 6.3bln European M&A foray by Japanese megabank MUFG. GBP/USD nursed recent losses as Brexit-related news quietened, although PM May continues to face challenges to her leadership with former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said to have held private talks with the DUP. Elsewhere, antipodeans were indecisive as participants awaited the Chinese trade data and as early momentum in AUD/USD faded after the RBA Financial Stability Review noted increased risks in the household sector and uncertainty regarding consumption outlook, while SGD was choppy in the aftermath of mixed GDP data and the Monetary Authority of Singapore’s semi-annual policy meeting where it maintained FX-based policy settings but lowered CPI forecasts.

RBA Financial Stability Review said risks in the household sector have increased and consumption outlook is uncertain but added the financial system is more resilient and banks have higher, more liquid capital. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were rangebound overnight amid a tentative risk tone as participants awaited the latest Chinese trade figures. WTI crude futures consolidated after its recent decline to below USD 64.00/bbl amid reports the June OPEC meeting is to debate raising oil output if crude hits USD 80-85/bbl and if supply from Venezuela and Iran falls further. Elsewhere, gold was lacklustre and failed to benefit from a softer greenback with the precious metal despondent after it recently gave up the USD 1300/oz level, while copper prices were more resilient and extended on the intraday rebound seen during US hours but with upside limited by the looming China data.

 

PDVSA reportedly shipped 1mln barrels of crude in two tankers to Cuba. (Newswires)

 

Libya NOC chief said oil and gas exports face biggest threat since 2011 given the recent fighting. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he would support easing on the sanctions on North Korea at the right time but sanctions on the country are at a fair level right now. US President Trump added that North Korea did not fulfil what he wanted them to in the talks and that he is discussing further meeting with North Korea, while he also noted that South Korea has agreed to purchase 'tremendous' amounts of military equipment. (Newswires) 

US

The implied probability for a Fed rate cut in 2019 fell to sub-50%, from around 55% on Wednesday, after decent jobless claims data and an upside surprise to PPI. However, ranges were low, and volumes were hardly exciting. Fed speakers added little new to the narrative, generally reiterating current positions and the central bank’s neutral stance (in line with yesterday’s minutes). This week’s auction series have been mixed, and after a solid 10-year sale on Wednesday, which stopped through by 1bps, Thursday’s sale of 30s was ok, tailing by 0.6bps, though direct participation fell slightly, picked-up by the indirects. At settlement, major curve spreads were a touch wider. US T-note futures (M9) settled 7+ lower at 123-18.

Fed Chair Powell (neutral) reiterated that rates are in the right place. Sources also reported that he believes China's soft patch impacted US growth outlook. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said if Fed keep rates low to spur wage growth that should also translate into lower mortgage costs which should help housing. Kashkari also commented that there is still slack in the labor market and therefore not yet at maximum employment, while he added that inflation is still below target so no need to tap the brakes. (Newswires/Twitter)
